fields.description:
When looking at the list of pull requests in Stash, it's sometimes not clear which code reviews I've completed. Here are some items that would be nice to haves.

* The list of review icons should always show my icon first. 
* Some prominent indication of review's that I've completed, like a status icon to the left of the review title, with a checkmark for complete reviews or colored text for the various states (merge needed, complete, open review, etc)
* support for Gravatar and fallback identicons. 

Also, Stash / bitbucket is an awesome product. :)
fields.summary: Pull request UI could communicate state in an easier to read fasion.

fields.description:
I would like task display order to be top to bottom by order of creation.

Currently: when I create task1 then create task2, Bitbucket displays task2 above task1.

What I want: when I create task 1 then create task2, task 1 should be displayed above task2 to reflect the logical order in which task should be done
fields.summary: Task display order in pull request comments

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian status as of June 2020|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3c78b5|titleBGColor=#3c78b5|bgColor=#e7f4fa}
Hi everyone,

Thanks for your advocacy and feedback on this suggestion. Starting with [Bitbucket Server and Data Center 7.3|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/bitbucket-server-7-3-release-notes-1005327661.html], the delete source branch after merging option will now be *selected by default* when you merge a pull request. If this isn’t your preferred setting, you can change it and we’ll remember your choice for next time (using browser's local storage).

Some of you in comments had requested an admin setting or branch pattern based setting for deleting branches post merge - it is not on our roadmap, please create a seperate suggestion for it. If you need to delete branches in bulk, then please provide your feedback on this suggestion - https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BSERV-4142

Edit 12-June-20: There is bug due to which preference is not stored in the local storage and it will be fixed soon. You can track it here https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BSERV-12407  

Edit 19-June-20: The issue related to preference not being stored in local storage has been fixed in 7.3.1 https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BSERV-12407 

Cheers,
 Imran Khan
 Product Manager - Bitbucket Server
{panel}
*Original request description* 

Customers might end up having a lot of dead branches laying around in Stash / Bitbucket Server because developers who do merges do not always check the "Delete source branch after merging" option. 
 There should be a way to configure Stash / Bitbucket Server to enable the "delete branch" option for all pull requests as the default, in order to force developers to uncheck the option if they actually wanted to keep the branch.

Actually, it would be better to configure the option based on branch name patterns. For example branches named "releases/*" the default would be to NOT delete the branch.
fields.summary: Allow "Delete source branch after merging" to be enabled by default

fields.description:
There are a number of Pull Request settings already to manage various requirements in order to merge a PR, but there is not a setting to control whether or not a PR can be merged if it is flagged as "Needs Work"

The description that's displayed if you hover over the "Needs Work" button says "Needs Work. This pull request shouldn't be merged yet", but there is no setting to actually enforce this behavior. 

It would be great if this option was added to the standard Pull Request settings.
fields.summary: Add Pull Request setting to block a merge if a Pull Request "Needs Work"

fields.description:
In Bitbucket 4.9 we will have the ability to create *default reviewers* for a project.  Default reviews provide the ability to specify *reviews required*, but *do not distinguish between reviewer types*.

As teams grow, we would like to increase the number of default reviewers to include new members so they are privy to recently published code.  New team member should be considered *optional* as often they don't have the depth of understanding needed for the review and are included for learning purposes.

Reviews required should only be applied to *mandatory reviewers* that are specified for the project

{panel}
Example:
*Mandatory Reviewers*
- James Apple
- John Banana

*Optional Reviewers*
- New Hire One
- New Hire Two

*Reviews Required*
- 1
{panel}

_This implies either James or Jon must complete their review for the pull request to be approved_
fields.summary: Ability to tag default reviewers as mandatory or optional

fields.description:

 # Add a comment
 # Click the delete button (notice cancel is highlighted)
 !delete-comment-dialog.png!
 # Press enter

Expected: delete is cancelled (because "Cancel" is focused)

Actual: comment gets deleted (delete action)
fields.summary: Deleting comment dialog should follow focus and cancel when enter is pressed

fields.description: It would be nice to have the ability to click and select multiple lines in a Stash review, and create a comment to apply to all of those lines. At the moment, it is only possible to add comments on specific lines.
fields.summary: Allow comments in Stash Reviews to be multi line

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Under some conditions, the Apache Mina SSH server bundled with Bitbucket Server may leak SSH session objects.  Under some extreme conditions, this may cause Out Of Memory Errors. 

If you open and close a connection really fast it seems to hold onto lots of them in IoServiceListenerSupport.
In the wild this can be caused by haproxy health checks.

h3. Steps to Reproduce

The problem can be reproduced in environments where you're [Setting up SSH port forwarding|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BitbucketServer/Setting+up+SSH+port+forwarding] but you left a {{check port}} statement on your HAProxy. I.e:
{noformat}
backend your-backend--ssh
        mode tcp
        server your-server-hostname-stash <YOUR_BTIBUCKET_IP>:7999 check port 7999
{noformat}

h3. Expected Results
The session object number in the JVM Heap is small.

h3. Actual Results
If you set up a Heap Dump on an instance that runs out of memory, you would be able to see huge number of objects:

The data below was extracted from an actual customer's heap dump:
{noformat}
Class                                            Objects         Shallow Size       Retained Size
org.apache.sshd.server.session.ServerSession      328234           97157264          359743528
org.apache.sshd.common.future.DefaultCloseFuture  984456           31502592          41998144
org.apache.sshd.common.util.Buffer                328234           7877616           97156992
{noformat}

This condition could lead to an {{OutOfMemoryError}} 24-72 hours after your instance has started up.

This problem has been raised against Apache. See [DIRMINA-1021|https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/DIRMINA-1021] for further information.

h3. Workaround

Remove the statement {{check port 7999}} from your HAProxy configuration.
fields.summary: Bitbucket Server may leak SSH sessions under some conditions

fields.description:
It would be nice to be able to designate the difference between people who have input on a review and the actual gatekeepers of a codeline (or owners of specific areas within a codeline) who have to provide approval for a change to be accepted.

The checks for handling the auto-merging of requests should be able to distinguish that X number of gatekeepers (rather than X number of reviewers overall) approve the review.

Additionally within this concept, it would be useful to allow gatekeepers to delegate their approval powers to another reviewer on a per review basis review for cases where someone else is the better technical expert on a specific item
fields.summary: Distinguish between Approvers and Reviewers

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Pull Requests are not maintaining file read status

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# create a pull request between 2 branches with at least 2 commits in the PR
# once the PR is created, go to the Diff tab and click all the files to show as "read"
# git revert the from branch back to the first commit in the PR
# force-push the commit to the from branch
# go back into the PR and look at the Diff tab.

h3. Expected Results
Pull Requests maintain the file read status

h3. Actual Results
Pull Requests are not maintaining file read status
 
h3.Workaround
No Workaround
fields.summary: Pull Requests are not maintaining file read status

fields.description:
h2. About "garbage collection" and Git LFS objects

Operations like removing a branch or rewriting history in Git, _might_ generate unreferenced objects. The same might happen for "Git LFS" objects. Whilst "Git" has {{git gc}} which, amongst other actions, removes unreferenced objects, "Git LFS" doesn't implement a similar process and, due to its nature, a considerable disk space might be taken up on its "content server" for teams whose Git workflow fits into this description.

h2. Why Bitbucket server does not implement that and the problem in more details
The main issue with "Git LFS" is that the specification does not describe "garbage collection". This is why we didn't implement it in the first place. When we wrote Git LFS we thought about that and it all boils down to how "Git LFS" works. Unlike "Git", its nature is of a centralised "Git LFS store" with its files in the commit history being checked out on demand by the developers as the files which depend on Git LFS simply contain instructions on how to fetch the "Large File" from the server.

To put that in perspective, let's think about 2 developers (A and B) who checked out a "Git LFS" repository. The Developer A does some work off a certain branch (that was originally Developer's B branch) and is working on a feature locally. Turns out that developer B decided to delete the branch that Developer A had branched off. That means that, if we were to garbage collect "Git LFS" objects on the server, we could potentially be breaking Developer's A work as we would have to remove all the objects from the aforementioned branch, leaving Developer A without access to those objects when attempting to checkout a previous commit on the branch, for example. On Git, that wouldn't be a problem as everyone has a full copy of the repository (i.e. when each commit on the branch pulls all the files down - there is no such concept as "go to the content server and give me a certain file"). See our [Git LFS Tutorial|https://www.atlassian.com/git/tutorials/git-lfs/] for a more detailed explanation on "Git LFS".

The second main reason is another complicating factor as to how our application is architected around Forks.

h2. Why would customers benefit from this?

At the moment there is no way to perform that (apart from very complicated and unsupported manual operations) but customers whose workflows might generate many unreferenced "Git LFS" objects could benefit from that in the future even though every "Git LFS" garbage collection will be a risky operation.
fields.summary: Provide a way to perform collection of unreferenced Git LFS objects

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

At the moment Bitbucket Server does not embed any CI tool.

\*\*\* More information needed \*\*\*

What is it about an embedded CI tool that you are seeking? What would it do that the current Bamboo integration doesn't?
h3. Suggested Solution

It would be nice to have an integrated build feature (such as [Bitbucket Pipelines|https://bitbucket.org/product/features/pipelines]) implemented in Bitbucket Server.
h3. Workaround

The recommended approach is to integrate [Bamboo|http://www.atlassian.com/software/bamboo.html] and Bitbucket server for behind the firewall continuous delivery.
fields.summary: Bitbucket Pipelines for Bitbucket Server

fields.description:
Hi,

With [Notifyr|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/nl.stefankohler.stash.stash-notification-plugin/server/overview] I'm sending notifications when a user pushed a commit to a repository. This works well and many customers are happy with the added functionality.

I have some requests from users to update the From address, to reflect the user who pushed the changes. Preferable I would do that in the format {{"<user name> (<App Name>)"<<ServerMailAddress>>}} ie: {{"Stefan Kohler (Bitbucket)" <bitbucket@example.com>}}

For what I can tell, the From address only accepts a String, and not an InternetAddress. The underlying {{MimeMailMessage}} does support this. It would be great if this is also exposed in the {{MailMessage}} and {{MailService}}.

Kind regards,
Stefan
fields.summary: Ability to set From as InternetAddress in MailService

fields.description:
I am currently using Bitbucket Server 4.7.1 and git 2.8. In this version of Bitbucket Server pull requests are being blocked by certain submodule modifications that git can't handle when using the no fast forward strategy.

Example:

Let's say I create a submodule in a repo on the master branch and then in a later commit use the {{git mv}} command to move that submodule to a different file path. If I then attempt to merge my moved submodule via pull request into the master branch the pull request will be blocked saying that there is a merge conflict. This is because the background merge uses the {{no-ff}} option when computing the trial merge. If I perform the merge locally, git elects to use a fast forward merge strategy and the merge is able to complete successfully. In other words, using the {{--no-ff}} option is causing the merge with the submodule change to fail. The workaround is to perform the merge locally and then push to the target branch, effectively ruining our pull request only workflow.

In Bitbucket Server 4.9 the merge strategy capabilities have been updated to allow a user to choose which merge strategy to use when performing the merge. This makes it possible to use the fast forward strategy when merging a pull request with an above described submodule change and merge the pull request successfully. However, and here is the suggestion for future improvement, the background trial merge does not use the default merge strategy defined for the repository. This means that even though the default merge strategy is fast forward, the user will see a message like {{Bitbucket Server could not create the merge diff for this pull request}} because the background merge still uses the {{--no-ff}} strategy and now the user will have to bravely attempt the merge not sure if it will succeed or if they're doing the right thing. I think it would be great if the default merge strategy was the one used for the background merge. If would also be nice if git could handle submodule moves in a non-fast forward fashion but I'll take that up with the git people themselves.

 

Edit: there seems to be a bug in JIRA that isn't letting me type {{--no-ff}} easily, fyi.
fields.summary: Background pull request merge should use default merge strategy

fields.description:
h2. Problem description:

According to [https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BitbucketServer/Search+for+code+in+Bitbucket+Server], {{proj:}} can be used to narrow down results to a specific project. This is incorrect as only {{project:}} can be used.

 
h2. Original reported description:

 

In my test repository the following doesn't return and search results:

 
{code:java}
proj:SEAR repository:searches digs-product-marker_primary
 


{code}
!Screen Shot 2016-10-17 at 14.50.30.png|thumbnail!

But the following does:

 
{code:java}
project:SEAR repository:searches digs-product-marker_primary
 


{code}
!Screen Shot 2016-10-17 at 14.50.41.png|thumbnail!  

Similarly, using {{repo}} instead of {{repository}} leads to no results being returned. The result of using and abbreviation or not is not consistent because sometimes they do not work and others one or the other will work.

 According to [https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BitbucketServer/Search+for+code+in+Bitbucket+Server] I should be abel to use either.

Also, there is no clear way to tell why the search has returned no results.
fields.summary: Search Documentation says that 'proj:' is a valid modifier

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Currently Bitbucket Server will happily run even if the database is running an unsupported version or if important configuration options are incorrectly set or not set at all.

While this may not cause problems in the beginning, it is very likely to cause problems as the use of Bitbucket Server picks up. For instance, when using SQL Server Bitbucket Server [requires specific settings|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BitbucketServer/Connecting+Bitbucket+Server+to+SQL+Server] in order to achieve optimal performance at scale.
h3. Suggested Solution

On startup, Bitbucket Server should verify:
 * that the version of the database it is connected to is supported
 * that the required configuration options are in place correctly (these will differ on the database type)

If any of these conditions are not met, Bitbucket Server should output a descriptive error message with references to the relevant documentation, and should shut down again (or otherwise prevent the use of the instance).
h3. Workaround

There is no workaround.
fields.summary: As an administrator I want Bitbucket Server not to start if the database is not running a supported configuration

fields.description: We use BitBucket cloud. Sometimes I need a file(s) from some repository. I have to check it out which is not convenient, especially behind our corporate VPN. I miss GitHub features. I would like to have direct download link or download folder as zip link.
fields.summary: Direct download

fields.description:
For example, as a reviewer, you have a branch with 10 commits, after a few commits the pull request becomes pretty long and you're not particularly concerned with all of the changes, you're only concerned with the ongoing changes.  

Very frequently I find myself viewing the "activity" tab of a pull request and viewing new, individual, commits and adding my comments there.

However, the comments that I add to an individual commit don't appear in the pull request itself, so inevitably I need to go through and copy all of my comments, find the relevant file in the pull request diff and add the comment a second time.

Since all new commits to a branch are considered a part of the pull request, so should all comments for each of those commits.
fields.summary: In a pull request, display any comments from commits to the same branch.

fields.description: For example, I would like to be automatically added to all pull requests on a given project so no code can be submitted without me knowing. I noticed there are watches that allow notifications when a branch is created or merged but that's not sufficient.
fields.summary: Bitbucket needs a way to request to become a reviewer of all pull requests against a given project.

fields.description:
h3. Summary
When using the 4.10.0 Windows installer, Bitbucket Server sets the *Log On As* account to "Local System Account" instead of "atlbitbucket"

h3. Environment
Tested on Windows 8.1

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Start with a clean instance of Windows
# Run {{atlassian-bitbucket-4.10.0-x64.exe}}
# Choose "New Installation"
# Choose to install the service

h3. Expected Results
* The service will use the "atlbitbucket" account

h3. Actual Results
* Bitbucket Server sets the *Log On As* account to "Local System Account"

h3. Notes
* Tested the 4.8.4 installer and "atlbitbucket" was the account assigned.

h3.Workaround
* Since we do not have the account password for "atlbitbucket" we can not change the account used manually. Therefore no workaround.
fields.summary: Windows Installer for 4.10 sets the service to "Local System Account"

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
PostgreSQL is now available:
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/9.6/static/release-9-6.html

+Note:+ Bitbucket Server < 4.11 does not support PostgreSQL 9.6. If PostgreSQL is upgraded earlier, check the possible workarounds on the ["Bitbucket Server fails to load pages due to "Could not get unique fields for table" errors"|https://confluence.atlassian.com/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=857065451] page.

h3. Suggested Solution
Provide support for the PostgreSQL version 9.6.
fields.summary: Support for PostgreSQL 9.6

I see the veto message from the plugin

I'm shown instructions on how to resolve a merge conflict

fields.description:
Hey,

There is really no reason to use a big red header on the dialog shown when deleting an already merged branch from the server. Red should be reserved for actions that are destructive; deleting a merged branch is not destructive as the branch can always be recreated.

I would love to see the "Delete branch" dialog having a green header when the branch being deleted has already been merged. We basically shouldn't fear cleaning up the merged branches..

Johan
fields.summary: An easy one: Green header when deleting merged branch

fields.description:
If the base URL does not match the URL used to navigate to Bitbucket Server, the following banner is shown:
"You are accessing Bitbucket from a URL that does not match the configured base URL. You may want to change it."

Updating the base URL removes the banner. If the user would like to keep the base URL unchanged, offer an option to dismiss the warning permanently.
fields.summary: Add an option to dismiss the base URL warning banner

fields.description:
Hello,

I recently open'd a [question about tag ordering|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/43107659/] in bitbucket overview, where i noticed an alphabetical ordering instead of number ordering, which leads to version 6.10.0 to be placed before 6.2.0 in my list.

The x.y.z is a very used format for version numbers, another user explained that the ordering is called [precedence rules|http://semver.org/#spec-item-11]. I'd like to know if we could have an option to order it as 3 numbers separated by a separator (a point, in that case), so that 6.10.0 is placed right after 6.9.8. 

I believe this is a minor feature, although would bring visual accuracy for the tag overview in BitBucket.

Thank you very much !
fields.summary: Option for number format ordering for tag versions in BitBucket

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Often times, we have SSH Keys at the project level, but we cannot see them at the repo level. See [SSH access keys for system use|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BitbucketServer/SSH+access+keys+for+system+use] to find out more about this feature. Basically:
- Project SSH Access Keys apply to every repository in the project.
- Repository SSH Access Keys for a particular repository apply to that repository _only_

h3. Suggested Solution
It would be helpful if when looking at the Repository SSH Access Keys it also showed any usable keys that are at the Project Level - maybe have these greyed out and notate that they are at the project level?
 
h3. Workaround 
Not available.
fields.summary: Show project-level access keys when viewing repository SSH access keys

fields.description:
Please reconsider putting Bitbucket in read-only mode when the number of users exceeds the license.  While this process makes sense to ensure that every user is paid for, it places an extreme hardship for large organizations with long purchasing time frames.

Consider the following scenario.

When a 10 user license customer exceeds their license by 1 user they are over the limit by 10% and it impacts 11 users.  When a 5000 user license customer exceeds their license by 1 user they are over the limit by .0002% but 5001 users are no longer able to work.

The customer with a 10 user license can likely pull out a credit card and add on an additional 10 users to their license and be back up and running in a few minutes.  The customer with a 5000 users license most likely works for a large corporation and has to make a requisition, get approval, and submit an order.  While they do have the ability to call and get a temporary license while that process is taking place, there is still the possibility that if this happened at the start of a three-day weekend that this could become catastrophic downtime.

Some adjustments were made to Bitbucket to allow for a 24 hour grace period but this doesn't go far enough.

Consider one or more of the following:
- Weighted grace period based on the number of licenses already purchased.
  -- 1 - 10: No grace period
  -- 11 - 100: 24 Hour grace period
  -- 101 - 1000: 72 Hour grace period
  -- 1001 - 5000: 168 Hour grace period
  -- 5000+: 720 Hour grace period
- Provide a warning to Sys Admins when they are approaching 80%, 90% and then 95% of their license 
- Provide a one click option on the license page to instantly increase the number of licenses by 10% that is valid for 1 week.
fields.summary: Please reconsider placing Bitbucket in read only mode when license is exceeded.

fields.description:
It would be useful to query whether automerging has been enabled for a repository from the REST API. It would also be useful to be able to toggle it on and off remotely. The branch model REST endpoint doesn't include whether automerging is enabled which is where I would expect it to be based on the location of the setting in the UI.

The reason this would be useful for me is that I am writing a custom plugin that changes its functionality based on whether automerging is enabled or not. I'd like to write integration tests that can remotely toggle the automerging setting on on and off to adaquately cover the code paths in my plugin.
fields.summary: Add the ability to modify whether automerging is enabled for a repository via the REST API

fields.description:
On the 'Create Pull Request' screen, there is a drop down to suggest that we can select a different repository as the destination. We have a use case for this kind of Pull Request in our repository, as we use a sandbox repository as well as a staging repository, the latter containing our train branches but also being read only (sans our automation) because it is the repo we submit code from. We do not allow the Pull Request to be Merged via the button, and our intent is to only use this facility for review.

Short of creating the equivalent train branches in our sandbox repository and having to keep them up to date, could we have the Source and Destination drop downs work by showing other repositories we have access to?
fields.summary: Allow cross repository diffs

fields.description:
If I have 2 users with the same name and email but a different usernames, commits are associated with the username that is listed first alphabetically.

It would be helpful if the correct username that should be associated with the commit can either be specified prior to the commit being pushed to Bitbucket Server or if the username attribute of the \{\{.git/config}} can be taken into account in addition to the email attribute.
fields.summary: As a user, I'd like to be able to specify which user/username is associated with a commit in the event 2 users have the same email

fields.description:
I'd like to see the (latest) contributions on a user's details page:

https://bitbucket.example.com/admin/users/view?name=u.name

For example, see a list of the projects or repositories and have the ability to fold it out to see specific commits.

I'd like to have this to see to what the user has contributed to and also have an indication of when a user has been active (for the last time)
fields.summary: Show latest contributions for a user

fields.description: Now that https://ecosystem.atlassian.net/browse/APL-1327 has been fixed, upgrade application-links to a version that contains a fix for it. In this case Bitbucket server would update application-links from version 5.2.2 to version 5.2.4.
fields.summary: Update application-links to fix APL-1327

fields.description:
We are missing information about the associated branch for a commits shown in the jira-integration. It would be very helpful to get this information, especially on cherry-picked commits. Else we just se a lot of commits, but have to look into each commit to get the information on which branch the commit was pushed.

See attached screenshot for further information. The two boxes show commits with the same commit-message, as they got cherry-picked to different branches, but no information is shown about the branch.

Maybe there could be an additional column for the corresponding branch of a commit?

Thanks and greets
Daniel
fields.summary: Show branch-information in bitbucket commit-popup

fields.description: This feature is more needed for bitbucket, but I'd love the ability to login to multiple accounts at once, and toggle/switch between them (just like google account switcher works). There are many situations where I need to toggle back & forth between company accounts and user accounts, and right now logging out, logging back in is a time impediment when this has to be done often and frequently.
fields.summary: implement multi-user account switching

fields.description:
It would be great if personal repositories in Bitbucket were made more visible / prominent. As of now, a new user logging in can see a list of formal projects with repositories. There is no similar mechanism to find more informal, single-developer projects. The closest thing to this is the "View All Public Repositories" link pointing to [https://bitbucket.example.org/repos?visibility=public]. This is problematic because the repository is only discoverable if it is public; it remains hidden if it only has permissions for a particular group.

I would suggest an additional UI to browse personal repositories by Group and by User. Alternatively, include Users in the Projects "dashboard" of Bitbucket.
fields.summary: Make personal repositories more visible.

fields.description: We would like to have this control in Bitbucket Server to reject users push some file types (Ex: EXE, PDF, ...). I know there are some add-ons out there, but they just cannot apply for the instance globally, and doesn't have an option to separate the blocking action for LFS / non-LFS
fields.summary: Ability to block some file-types globally with option on LFS objects

fields.description: It would be desirable if the Bitbucket Server Docker container could be run in "mirror mode".
fields.summary: Bitbucket Server Docker container: Support mirror mode

fields.description:
Since 4.6 the Docker image available from [https://hub.docker.com/r/atlassian/bitbucket-server/] ends up starting both Bitbucket Server itself but additionally the bundled Elasticsearch instance.

This is undesirable as it prevents the Docker image from being able to be used for production deployments (where only the actual instance should be running) and in particular for data center deployments as a local Elasticsearch will not be useful in that scenario. 

[https://docs.docker.com/engine/userguide/eng-image/dockerfile_best-practices/] contains:
{quote}
Run only one process per container

In almost all cases, you should only run a single process in a single container. Decoupling applications into multiple containers makes it much easier to scale horizontally and reuse containers. If that service depends on another service, make use of [container linking|https://docs.docker.com/engine/userguide/networking/default_network/dockerlinks/].
{quote}
Which pretty much sums this up.

The advantage of the current situation is that search just works out of the box without any further configuration. 

Instead of relying on the bundled instance we should either:
 * Document how to run and link a Bitbucket Server and the Elasticsearch container.
 * Provide a docker compose file that runs both correctly configured.

This would re-enable the use of the Docker image for production deployments as it will avoid running another process inside the container.

Other options that retain the current behaviour might include the usage of environment variables to enable/disable running the bundled Elasticsearch instance.
fields.summary: Make Bitbucket Server Docker container configure external Elasticsearch instead of the bundled Elasticsearch

fields.description:
h3. Summary
 
If a users' username contains a space, no one can access that user's personal repositories including the user.
 
h3. How to Replicate
 
# In Bitbucket Server 4.4.1, create a user with a space in the username. {{test user}}
# Fork a repository to the users' personal project.

Results: You can access the users' repository and the personal project page is visible to the user.

# Upgrade Bitbucket Server from 4.4.1 to 4.9.1
# Attempt access to the personal repository or project page for user {{test user}}

Results: You receive a 404 error stating that - "No project with key '~test%20user' exists."
fields.summary: If username contains a space, access to user projects return 404

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Currently project admins are unable to add team members to groups for the purpose of giving them access to repositories, and it is tedious for global admins to have to do this for them.

h3. Suggested Solution
Allow project administrators to be able to edit which users belong to which group.
This should only be allowed for a subset of groups.
 
h3. Workaround
- Grant the permissions to the individual users.
- Grant the Admin permissions to the Project Admins
fields.summary: As an admin, I want the "Project Admin" to control which users belong to which group

fields.description:
For Bitbucket Server DC with using NFS is most important is network performance between NFS server and nodes. But there are one trick to bust one node. You can run node directly on NFS server and it got local disk access speed, without network.

So, will be nice to have option that can mark node as Superfast Local storage NODE, this can be only one.

And also, will be nice to have option to schedule and run ClusterJobs with flag `ONCE_ON_FAST_NODE`, with similar to `ONCE_PER_CLUSTER`, but only run job on node with local disk access.
fields.summary: Superfast node marker

fields.description: In the diff view for a particular pull request, some of the wrong lines are being colored red and green. It looks like the highlight is supposed to be on the line directly below. Also, there is an extra line at the bottom of the diff, below the "cut" or "rip". The colors seem to line up until after a line that just includes a "\", so perhaps that could be triggering the problem?
fields.summary: Pull request diff shows changes on wrong line

fields.description:
By default Bitbucket Server is installed with a configured maximum heap size of 768m. This allocates 512m to the old generation and the remainder to the young generation (eden, survivor).

If some plugins are installed, coupled with the base memory usage of the product, it is possible to fill the old generation. In this regime the GC can performance consecutive full, and very poor performance results.

In Bitbucket Server 4.10 we move from the standard throughput collector to the G1 collector. This collector has been demonstrated to provide superior performance in this scenario. It is also slated to be the [default collector in Java 9|http://openjdk.java.net/jeps/248].
fields.summary: Enable G1 Garbage Collector by default

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Elasticsearch can use a significant amount of space for the indexed content.

h3. Suggested Solution
Provide the option to configure the details of what is indexed. Some alternatives may be:
- exclude forks
- exclude specific paths in a repository
- exclude specific projects and/or repositories
fields.summary: ElasticSearch takes up lots of disk space

fields.description:
The [Bitbucket Server config properties|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/bitbucket-server-config-properties-776640155.html] document mentions that the maximum number of segment lines for a single diff can be configured by adding / editing the {{page.max.diff.lines}} property at {{$BITBUCKET_HOME/shared/bitbucket.properties}}, but this property is not being used.

When this property is not configured, the default maximum is 20000 lines and this default value is used.

[This sample huge text file|http://norvig.com/big.txt] contains 128458 lines and can be used in order to validate this problem.
h3. Correct behavior:
 # Commit and push a huge file
 # Make sure that the property is *not* configured in {{bitbucket.properties}} so as to use the default maximum of 20000 lines.
 # Open the huge file
 # Scroll to the bottom of the page
 # Check that 20000 lines have correctly been displayed, and the following message shows up:{panel}(!)   This file is too large to render. Download the full file.
{panel}

h3. Wrong behavior:
 # Commit and push a huge file
 # Configure the {{page.max.diff.lines}} property in {{bitbucket.properties}} in order to allow *70000* lines:
{noformat:title=bitbucket.properties}
page.max.diff.lines=70000

{noformat}

 # Restart Bitbucket Server
 # Open the huge file
 # Scroll to the bottom of the page
 # Check that *20000* lines (instead of *70000*) have been displayed, and the following message shows up:{panel}(!) This file is too large to render. Download the full file.
{panel}
fields.summary: Configurable maximum number of segment lines for diffs not working

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Currently in {{Administration >> Server Settings}} under *Mail Settings*, the *Email From* field only accepts email addresses.

h3. Expected Results
Per [the Email Address Wikipedia page | https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Email_address#Overview], using a Display Name in the format {{Display Name <from@address.net>}} as part of the FROM header should also be acceptable.

h3. Actual Results
After clicking *Save* you receive the message {color:red}Please enter a valid email address{color}

h3.Workaround
No workaround other than to omit a Display Name
fields.summary: Unable to use a Display Name in the Email From field for Mail Settings
The format
French translation for bitbucket.web.scm.resource.queueing.tooltip appears to be double-escaped

fields.description:
The {{/rest/branch-permissions/2.0/projects/\{projectKey}/repos/\{repositorySlug}/restrictions}} REST API endpoint requires a {{Id}} as part of the payload.

In the Bitbucket Server GUI it would be useful if a branch's \{\{Id}} had its own column (or displayed when the branch name is hovered over) on the Bitbucket Server > Repo > Settings > Branch Permissions page once the branch permission is created.

 

That would allow confirming if the \{\{Id}} was entered correctly in the API call.

 

From tests performed in this regard, if the \{\{Id}} is not correct the permission will still be created but not enforced.
fields.summary: Show ID for a branch permission in the UI to assist with constructing REST API call for the same

fields.description:
When small changes are made inside of a large method, the diff viewer only shows a small excerpt with the change, usually not including the name of the method that was modified.

It would be ideal if the diff viewer showed the name of the function that these changes occurred in.
fields.summary: Show method name in PR diff for changes in the middle of a function

fields.description:
After the intorduction of -BSERV-2962- It would have been nice if the linked PR had an activity update message indicating that it had been mentioned from a comment elsewhere. (ie generate the reverse link). As it's very likely that those interested in the linked PR would be interested in the other PR that mentions it.
 Github has functionality like this.
fields.summary: Activity message on PR if mentioned

fields.description: Making a service call using elevated permissions (i.e.: through the {{SecurityService}}) may fail claiming the user cannot access the resource because in some scenarios the elevated permissions are ignored.
fields.summary: PermissionService ignores elevated permissions

fields.description:
h3. Summary
When importing code form an [existing project using the web interface|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BitbucketServer/Importing+code+from+an+existing+project#Importingcodefromanexistingproject-Importcodeusingthewebinterface], the import does not complete and it times out after 60 minutes.


h3. Environment
This problem has been observed in the following conditions, however it may be experienced when using a different source repository and operating system:
* Operating System: Windows Server 2012 R2
* Source repository: Bonobo
* When running the {{git config --list --show-origin}} command, the {{credential.helper=manager}} property is returned

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Select the Git option and provide the required connection information and credentials
# Start the importer

h3. Expected Results
The new repository is created and the source code is available.

h3. Actual Results
The below exception is thrown in the {{atlassian-bitbucket.log}} file:
{noformat}
ERROR [pool-9-thread-1] <username> @AZS1P7x875x2581x0 y9g4a7 100.100.341.306 "POST /rest/importer/latest/projects/<project_name>/import/repos HTTP/1.1" c.a.b.i.i.repository.RefSyncTask Failed to import repository: <project_name>/<repository_slug>[12]
com.atlassian.bitbucket.ServerException: An error occurred while executing an external process: process timed out
	at com.atlassian.bitbucket.scm.git.command.GitCommandExitHandler.evaluateThrowable(GitCommandExitHandler.java:113) ~[na:na]
{noformat}

h3.Workaround
# Import the repository by using the instructions provided in the "Import code using the terminal" on the [Importing code from an existing project|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BitbucketServer/Importing+code+from+an+existing+project#Importingcodefromanexistingproject-Importcodeusingtheterminal] page.
# Remove the git {{credential.helper=manager}} property from the server hosting Bitbucket Server
fields.summary: Importing a repository fails due to process timed out

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Testing the connection between Bitbucket Server and JIRA/Crowd for user authentication displays a misleading message about the UUID attribute not being set.
h3. Environment
 * Bitbucket Server connected to JIRA or Crowd for user management.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # After having Bitbucket Server connected to JIRA or Crowd and confirming the connection is working, go to {{Administration > User Directories}} and click in *Test* for the given user directory.
 # Type the credentials accordingly and execute the test.

h3. Expected Results
 * Assuming the connection works, the test should pass entirely.

h3. Actual Results
 * One of the outputs of the test is a warning stating:
{noformat}
Test user rename is configured and tracked : The Unique ID Attribute has been left blank. We recommend you set this to the attribute for the UUID of the user

{noformat}

This is a misleading message, since there's no UUID attribute to be set when using JIRA or Crowd, and can be ignored.
fields.summary: Misleading warn when connecting to JIRA/Crowd for user management

fields.description:
My add-on makes it possible to view very large diffs (10,000+ changes) but it doesn't support commenting on diff lines.  Since Bitbucket Server supports commenting on diff lines, but doesn't handle really large diffs, it would be nice if I could reference the commit page and tell Bitbucket to only show the diff for a single file.

For example, pass it some URL query parameter like path=foo/bar.html and have the commit page, only show the diff for the foo/bar.html file.  By supporting this feature and with my add-on, Bitbucket Server users will always be able comment on a diff.
fields.summary: Allow filtering of files in the commit viewer

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
When importing a repository from *Bitbucket Cloud* (bitbucket.org), the user interface only presents me with the list of repositories owned by me or by a team I belong to.
!BSERV9169_repositories.png|width=400px!
Repository shared with a user are not presented. For an end user it is not obvious why these repositories are not presented.

A similar behaviour can be observed when importing shared repositories from *GitHub*.

h3. Suggested Solution
Provide the list of repositories shared with a user.

h3. Workaround
These repositories can be imported by using the Git option and entering the {{Clone URL}}, the {{Username}} and the {{Password}} to access it.

REST API should expose whether a branch is active or not

fields.description:
h3. Problem

The merge button is not shown if you do not have REPO_WRITE permission.

This means none of the merge vetoes are visible to a pull request author if they do not have write access to the repository.
h3. Use case

If a repository has a fork based workflow whereby PR authors only have REPO_READ on the target repository and a "trusted user" is allowed to perform the merge as they will have REPO_WRITE, the author will not be able to see any merge vetoes as the merge button will be hidden.
h3. Proposed Solutions
 * Make a permission merge veto to inform a user that they do not have the right permission set to merge this pull request. This would always show the merge button to everyone that sees the pull request but disable it for users that only have REPO_READ.
 * Similar to the above, but instead of creating a separate merge veto, disable the button and add a message to the merge checks dialog to indicate the user does not have sufficient permissions to merge the pull request.
fields.summary: Add a permission merge veto to facilitate showing vetoes to the PR author regardless of permission level

fields.description:
It would make more sense if the GET API such as {{/rest/api/1.0/projects/\{projectKey}/permissions/users}} and {{/rest/api/1.0/projects/\{projectKey}/repos/\{repositorySlug}/permissions/users}} did not require {{REPO_ADMIN}} or {{PROJECT_ADMIN}} privileges.

Not sure why non-admin can't see this info (as long as they can't change it).
fields.summary: Allow project/repo permission viewing to NON project/repo admins

You can find more information in the Bitbucket Server 7.0 [release notes|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/bitbucket-server-7-0-release-notes-990546638.html].

Please, don't hesitate to leave feedback on the feature in the comments. This will help us to priorities further development.

Anton Genkin

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
In some cases (e.g. if the Bitbucket Backup client takes a long time to complete) we recommend to use the DIY backup instead of the client.

This is the currently available documentation:
- [Data recovery and backups|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BitbucketServer/Data+recovery+and+backups]
- [Using the Bitbucket Server Backup Client|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BitbucketServer/Using+the+Bitbucket+Server+Backup+Client]
- [Using Bitbucket Server DIY Backup|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BitbucketServer/Using+Bitbucket+Server+DIY+Backup]

h3. Suggested Solution
It would be useful to document the conditions that lead to use the DIY backup strategy.
fields.summary: Document the ratio for using the DIY backup strategy instead of the Bitbucket Backup

fields.description:
Every time I'm commenting on a pull request in Bitbucket, and I hit tab and enter to submit the comment, and it goes to the "markup syntax guide" instead because their tab order is wrong, part of me dies.

Part of me dies every time.

Please change the tab order so that tabbing out of the comment entry field brings you to the "Comment" button instead of to the '?'.

Please end my nightmare.
fields.summary: Commenting on PRs in Bitbucket –> Change to Logical Tab Order

fields.description:
According to the installation instructions here https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/set-up-a-mirror-790632894.html

"The setup wizard fields cannot be changed after you click Submit configuration, so fill them in carefully. If you do make a mistake and need to change a mirror's setup after it has been submitted, you need to stop the mirror, delete its home directory completely, and go back to step 2, Set up SSL on the mirror."

It actually seems we need to totally restart from Step one and install again, because deleting the home directory did not enable the server to start again.

In our case, we were having to debug through some issues in our HA Proxy and the certificates where we did not always have the proxy presenting the proper certificate, so the registration between the Smart Mirror and the main BitBucket server seems to only partially work (the master knew about the mirror, but could not connect to it).  Having an easier way to just restart this configuration process would be much better than having to revert back to reinstall.  Even simply being able to delete this single file that contained the mirror's configuration information would be preferable as a simple improvement if adding all the way back to the UI is too much effort.  This would only be an administrative type task anyway.
fields.summary: Need easier ability to reset the Smart Mirror server

fields.description: Use case: I need to search every repo to see what is using a specific function call "db_class_name". My only option as I see it is to search "db AND class AND name". This returns 2218 files. Too big. OK. I try "db AND class AND name AND ModuleName". This returns 350 files better but still too much to search through when most hits are fuzzy matches that have no relevance to this search. The actual module itself where the function is defined is halfway down the list.

* On the login page, the query disappears and it changes the query to https://<host>/plugins/servlet/search

* Upon logging in, since the search parameter is missing, the result page will not show anything

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Red Hat Enterprise Linux (RHEL) 7 ships with {{systemd}} as the default system init daemon, however Bitbucket still only provides {{initd}} startup scripts.

h3. Suggested Solution

Bitbucket Server should provide {{systemd}} compatible scripts if it detects that {{systemd}} is used instead of {{initd}}.
 
h3. Workaround

Manually create {{systemd}} script or use one of those available at https://github.com/bparsons/atlassian-systemd
fields.summary: As an administrator I want Bitbucket Server to provide systemd startup scripts so I can use them on RHEL 7

could you make Seoul to join?

fields.description:
The Atlassian Hipchat Integration Plugin for Bitbucket Server exposed the secret key it used to communicate with a linked HipChat service in various administration pages. For this vulnerability to affect your Bitbucket Server instance you must have a HipChat integration established. To exploit this issue, attackers must have Admin access to a Bitbucket Server. Using the secret key attackers could gain full control over a linked HipChat instance.

\\
 *Affected versions:*
 * All versions of *Atlassian Hipchat Integration Plugin* for Bitbucket Server from 6.26.0 before *6.27.5*, from *6.28.0* before *7.3.7* and from *7.4.0* before *7.8.17* are affected by this vulnerability.
 * All versions of *Bitbucket Server* from 3.10.0 before *4.4.4 *(the fixed version for 4.4.x), from *4.5.0* before *4.5.3* (the fixed version for 4.5.x), *4.6.0* before *4.6.4* (the fixed version for 4.6.x), *4.7.0* before *4.7.2* (the fixed version for 4.7.x) and from *4.8.0* before *4.8.4* are affected by this vulnerability.

*Fix:*
 * *Bitbucket Server* 4.9.1 is available for download from [https://www.atlassian.com/software/bitbucket/download].
 * *Bitbucket Server* 4.8.4 is available for download from [https://www.atlassian.com/software/bitbucket/download-archives.html].
 *Bitbucket Server* 4.7.2 is available for download from [https://www.atlassian.com/software/bitbucket/download-archives.html].
 * *Bitbucket Server* 4.6.4 is available for download from [https://www.atlassian.com/software/bitbucket/download-archives.html].
 * *Bitbucket Server* 4.5.3 is available for download from [https://www.atlassian.com/software/bitbucket/download-archives.html].
 * *Bitbucket Server* 4.4.4 is available for download from [https://www.atlassian.com/software/bitbucket/download-archives.html].

\\
If you are running Stash 3.11 then download the JARs from this issue and install them using the instructions for installing add-ons using UPM found at https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/UPM/Installing+add-ons#Installingadd-ons-Installingbyfileupload *after which you must restart Stash*. Version 6.27.5 (which contains a fix) of the Atlassian Hipchat Integration Plugin should be installed.  

\\
*Risk Mitigation:*
 * If you are unable to upgrade your Bitbucket Server, then as a *temporary workaround*, you can disable or uninstall the *Atlassian Hipchat Integration Plugin*.


\\
For additional details see the [full advisory|https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/0QkcMg].
fields.summary: CVE-2016-6668 - The HipChat plugin for various products leaks the secret key it uses to communicate with a linked HipChat instance.

fields.description:
Row lines between branch rules appear and disappear inconsistently across a mult-row table, especially if there are multiple rules configured for a branch pattern, or multiple users configured for a rule.

Row lines appear most reliably when scrubbing the mouse down the screen, and disappear when scrubbing upwards.

Row lines for the topmost set of branch rules don't display across the whole screen, unlike the other rows. This is crazy behaviour!

fields.description: We have the notion of a "key reviewer" that is in charge of a given review from beginning to end and ensures the review gets concluded.
